questions.text: A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is seen on the MRI. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Craniopharyngioma

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis for a cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification seen on MRI is a craniopharyngioma.
  • Craniopharyngiomas are benign tumors that arise from remnants of Rathke's pouch, which is an embryonic structure.
  • They are often located in the suprasellar region, near the pituitary gland. The presence of calcifications is a characteristic feature of craniopharyngiomas and can help differentiate them from other suprasellar lesions.

Craniopharyngioma

  • Craniopharyngiomas are suprasellar tumors that develop from remnants of the craniopharyngeal duct or Rathke’s pouch.
  • It compress Optic chaism leads to bitemporal hemianopia.
  • Adamantinomatous subtype
    • It is more common
    • Seen in children
    • Typically appear as large, lobulated, multiloculated cystic lesions with a small enhancing solid component and calcifications.
  • Papillary subtype
    • Seen in Adults
    • Primarily solid lesion
    • Rarely exhibit calcifications

Pituitary Adenoma (Option B)

Pituitary Microadenomas

  • Less than 10 mm in size.
  • Microadenomas appear isointense to the pituitary on T1-weighted images and slightly hyperintense on T2-weighted images.
  • In dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI, they enhance slowly compared to the surrounding pituitary gland.

Pituitary Macroadenomas

  • Larger than 10 mm in size.
  • Most of the macroadenomas are nonfunctioning.
  • They may cause endocrine disturbances or compress the optic chiasm, leading to bitemporal hemianopia.
  • Typically appear as sellar-suprasellar masses with a “snowman” or “figure of eight” appearance due to a waist at the diaphragma sellae.
  • The sella is usually enlarged.
  • These tumors can invade the cavernous sinuses.


 

Meningioma (Option C)
  • Meningiomas arise from arachnoidal cap cells in the brain and spinal cord coverings.
  • They are the most common benign intracranial tumors.
  • Most common in females
  • Mostly sporadic but can be linked to NF-2 or prior cranial irradiation.
  • Meningiomas are dural based extra-axial masses that appear isointense to gray matter on both T1 and T2-weighted images.
  • They demonstrate intense homogeneous enhancement on post-contrast imaging, accompanied by a dural tail sign.
  • Characteristic imaging features:
    • CSF cleft sign (thin layer of CSF around the mass)
    • Cortical buckling
    • Widening of the subarachnoid space with visible pial arteries/veins,
    • Hyperostosis or erosion of the calvarium.
    • Mother in law sign (early enhancement during the arterial phase and remain opacified long after the venous phase has passed)
    • Calcification

Oligodendroglioma (Option D)
  • Oligodendrogliomas are diffuse infiltrating glial tumors originating from oligodendrocytes and are characterized by IDH mutations and 1p/19q codeletion.
  • These tumors can be either WHO grade 2 (well-differentiated oligodendrogliomas) or WHO grade 3 (anaplastic oligodendrogliomas).
  • Typically occurs in the frontal lobe.
  • They are slow-growing, non-encapsulated, and tend to infiltrate the overlying cortex.
  • CT: Oligodendrogliomas are isodense to hypodense with calcification
  • MRI: Tumors are hypointense on T1 and hyperintense on T2. They generally do not enhance with contrast

questions.text: A patient presents with severe headache. A CT scan of the brain reveals hypodense areas in the right basal region, marked as ‘X’. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Subarachnoid hemorrhage:

Explanation:

  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) typically presents with a sudden, severe “thunderclap” headache, often described as the worst headache of life.
  • On non-contrast CT, acute blood in the subarachnoid space appears hyperdense (bright), especially in the basal cisterns, Sylvian fissures, and interhemispheric fissure.
  • When the blood fills the basal cisterns, the appearance is classically described as the “Star of Death” sign.
  • Hypodense areas may develop later due to ischemia or edema.
  • The most common cause is rupture of a saccular (berry) aneurysm at the circle of Willis.

Incorrect Options:

Meningococcal meningitis (Option B): CT often normal or with meningeal enhancement after contrast; no acute cisternal blood.

Brain abscess (Option C): Ring-enhancing lesion with surrounding edema; different appearance.

Pneumocephalus (Option D): Shows air density (dark areas) rather than bright hemorrhage.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accurate investigation to localize the lesion in a case of primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sestamibi scan

Explanation:

Sestamibi scan is a type of nuclear medicine-based study that is most accurate for parathyroid lesion localization.

  • It is safe and reproducible.
  • It has a sensitivity and specificity similar to ultrasound but may detect glands in ectopic positions better.
  • Sestamibi accumulates in the mitochondria and hence the rates at which it washes out differs as per the number of mitochondria in different tissues.
  • Parathyroid adenoma is rich in oxyphilic cells with a high concentration of mitochondria and hence has a lower washout than the thyroid gland.
  • False positives are rare and the sensitivity and specificity are 79% and 90% respectively.
  • Addition of a thyroid specific radioactive-tracer eliminates the chance of false positives.

Other investigations: Parathyroid angiography and venous sampling for parathyroid hormone.

Biochemical analysis is always to be done.

Incorrect Options:

Ultrasonography (Option A):

  • Parathyroid adenoma is identified as an oval/ elongated, bi or multiloculated hypoechoic structure.
  • Advantage: Can identify and facilitate biopsy of any concomitant thyroid pathology.
  • Disadvantage: Adenomas in retro-oesophageal, retrosternal, or retro-tracheal areas can be missed.

4D CT (Option C):

  • Rapid uptake and washout allow hyperfunctioning glands to be differentiated from lymph nodes that demonstrate a progressive enhancement pattern.
  • Disadvantage: Higher radiation dose than traditional imaging.

MRI (Option D):

  • Not commonly used, but helpful for preoperative cases or mediastinal adenomas.
  • Has poor resolution for small glands/adenomas <5 mm, and it is difficult to localize superior glands.

Biochemical tests:

Serum calcium levels

High

Intact PTH

Low or inappropriately high

Serum phosphate

Low

24-hour urinary calcium

High

Chloride to phosphate ratio

High

1,25- hydroxy Vitamin D

Normal or raised

Casanova test:

  • The modified Casanova test evaluates the long-term function of autotransplanted parathyroid glands. During the test, ischemic blockage is induced by a tourniquet, and PTH levels are measured.
  • A significant reduction in PTH indicates well-functioning autografts, while minimal change (≤20% of baseline) suggests functioning residual parathyroid tissue elsewhere.
  • This test can detect graft-dependent recurrent hyperparathyroidism and identify persistent hypoparathyroidism before surgery.

questions.text: Identify the condition associated with the MRI finding shown below:
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option A) Pantothenate Kinase deficiency

Explanation

  • Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN), formerly Hallervorden-Spatz disease(Option A): The classic MRI finding is the "eye-of-the-tiger" sign in the globus pallidus. This is characterized by bilateral, symmetric hypointensity (darker) on T2-weighted images with a central area of hyperintensity (brighter). This pattern is due to iron accumulation and neuronal loss.

Incorrect Options:

Wilson's disease(Option B ruled out): MRI findings in Wilson's disease can be varied but often involve the basal ganglia (especially the putamen and globus pallidus), brainstem, and thalami. Common findings include bilateral, symmetrical hyperintensities on T2-weighted images in these areas. There can also be atrophy and cavitations in chronic stages.

Krabbe's disease (Globoid cell leukodystrophy)(Option C ruled out): This is a white matter disease. MRI typically shows diffuse, symmetric white matter hyperintensities on T2-weighted images, often beginning in the posterior cerebral white matter and progressing anteriorly. There can also be involvement of the thalami and brainstem. In later stages, cerebral atrophy may be seen.

Huntington's chorea(Option D ruled out): The characteristic MRI finding in Huntington's disease is bilateral atrophy of the caudate nuclei and putamen. This can be seen as widening of the frontal horns of the lateral ventricles due to the loss of caudate head volume. Generalized brain atrophy may also be present in later stages.

questions.text: Based on the X-ray image provided, determine the type of thyroid malignancy:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)Follicular carcinoma

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario is a case of follicular carcinoma, in which the most common site of metastasis is bone, and the route is hematogenous.
  • Lymphatic spread is not seen.

Papillary carcinoma, Hürthle cell carcinoma, Thyroid lymphoma (Options A,B,D) are less likely to be spread hematogenously to bone

Follicular carcinoma (Option C): This is well-established as having a propensity for hematogenous spread, with the lungs and bones being common sites for distant metastases. Bone metastases from follicular carcinoma are relatively frequent compared to other thyroid cancers.

Incorrect Options:

Hürthle cell carcinoma (Option B ruled out): Often considered a more aggressive variant of follicular carcinoma, Hürthle cell carcinoma also commonly spreads hematogenously to distant sites, including the lungs and bones. But less likely than follicular carcinoma.

Papillary carcinoma (Option A ruled out): While papillary carcinoma is the most common type of thyroid cancer and often spreads via the lymphatic system to regional lymph nodes, hematogenous spread to distant sites like bone is less common compared to follicular or Hürthle cell carcinoma. However, it can occur, especially in aggressive subtypes.

Thyroid lymphoma (Option D ruled out): Thyroid lymphoma primarily involves the lymph nodes and can spread to other lymphatic tissues. While distant spread can occur, bone metastasis is not a typical or common route of spread for thyroid lymphoma compared to the other thyroid carcinoma types.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male patient presented with complaints of fever and cough. His chest radiograph shows an air bronchogram sign. The probable diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
Correct Option B.

  • In the given scenario, the presence of fever, cough, and an air bronchogram sign on the chest radiograph suggests the presence of consolidation. Consolidation refers to the filling of the alveoli with fluid, inflammatory exudates, or cellular infiltrates, leading to the solidification of lung tissue. It is commonly seen in conditions such as pneumonia, where the alveoli become filled with inflammatory cells, bacteria, and debris. The air bronchogram sign, which refers to the visualization of air-filled bronchi within the consolidated lung tissue, is a characteristic radiographic finding in consolidation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Pleural effusion: Pleural effusion is the accumulation of fluid in the pleural cavity, the space between the lung and the chest wall. It typically presents as blunting of the costophrenic angles on chest radiographs and may cause compression of lung tissue. However, it does not present with the air bronchogram sign seen in the given case.

Option C. Hilar lymphadenopathy: Hilar lymphadenopathy refers to the enlargement of lymph nodes in the hilar region of the lungs, which is commonly seen in conditions such as tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, or metastatic cancer. It may cause visible lymph node enlargement on chest radiographs, but it does not typically present with the air bronchogram sign seen in the given case.

Option D. Bronchiectasis: Bronchiectasis is a chronic condition characterized by abnormal, permanent dilation of the bronchi and bronchioles. It is associated with recurrent infections, excessive mucus production, and impaired clearance of secretions. While bronchiectasis can be seen on chest radiographs and may present with cough and recurrent respiratory infections, it does not typically present with the air bronchogram sign seen in the given case.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis based on the image of the scan given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Craniopharyngioma

  • The image provided corresponds to a craniopharyngioma, a benign brain tumor that arises near the pituitary gland.
  • Craniopharyngiomas can have significant effects on hormone production, vision, and overall brain function.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A: Pituitary apoplexy- Pituitary apoplexy refers to a sudden hemorrhage or infarction (loss of blood supply) in the pituitary gland. It typically presents with sudden-onset severe headache, visual disturbances, and hormonal abnormalities. However, the given image is showing a craniopharyngioma and not indicative of pituitary apoplexy.

Option B: Pituitary macroadenoma- Pituitary macroadenoma is a benign tumor of the pituitary gland that measures more than 1 centimeter in size. These tumors can cause hormonal imbalances, visual disturbances, and headaches. However, the given image specifically shows a craniopharyngioma and not a pituitary macroadenoma.

Option C: Rathke cleft cyst- A Rathke cleft cyst is a benign cystic lesion that develops from remnants of Rathke's pouch, an embryological structure that contributes to the development of the pituitary gland. These cysts are typically asymptomatic and incidental findings on imaging. They are different from craniopharyngiomas, which are solid tumors.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 50-year-old female patient who shows a progressive decline in visual clarity in her eye? A post-contrast CT scan of her head indicates the presence of thickening in a specific structure, in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Optic nerve sheath meningioma

Explanation:

The image given shows thickening around the optic nerve making the most likely diagnosis an Optic Nerve Sheath Meningioma.

Optic nerve sheath meningioma (ONSM) is a rare, benign tumor that originates from the meninges, the protective layers surrounding the optic nerve. It typically involves the optic nerve sheath and can lead to vision loss due to compression of the optic nerve.

Radiological Findings:

  1. MRI: The most common imaging modality for diagnosing ONSM. Key findings include:

    • Isointense or mildly hyperintense lesion on T1-weighted images.

    • Hyperintense lesion on T2-weighted images.

    • Contrast enhancement: The tumor usually enhances after gadolinium administration, especially in the meningothelial regions.

    • Enlargement of the optic nerve: The optic nerve may appear thickened and "sharply delineated," with the tumor surrounding it.

  2. CT: Less sensitive than MRI, but may show bone changes (hyperostosis of the optic canal) and optic nerve enlargement. 'Tram-track' appearance caused by thickening and enhancement around the optic nerve.

Optic nerve glioma (Option B): is incorrect because this tumor is more common in children and is associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). It presents with fusiform optic nerve enlargement, not optic sheath thickening.

Retinoblastoma (Option C): is incorrect because it occurs in children, typically under 5 years old, and presents with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) rather than progressive vision loss.

Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option D): is incorrect because it is a highly malignant soft tissue tumor seen in children, presenting with rapid-onset proptosis and orbital swelling, unlike the slow progression seen in ONSM.

questions.text: Identify the labelled structure in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Midbrain

Explanation:

The midbrain is a region of the brain located between the pons and the diencephalon. In a CT scan image, the midbrain appears as a centrally located structure, typically exhibiting a more dense and compact appearance compared to the surrounding brain tissue. It is characterized by its distinct shape and size, with a relatively smaller volume compared to other brain regions.

Pons (Option B): The pons is a part of the brainstem located above the medulla and below the midbrain. In a CT scan image, the pons appears as a rounded structure situated anterior to the cerebellum. It has a slightly lighter density compared to the adjacent brain tissue, and its size and shape can vary among individuals. The pons serves as a communication pathway, relaying signals between the cerebrum, cerebellum, and other parts of the central nervous system.

Medulla (Option C): The medulla, also known as the medulla oblongata, is the lowermost part of the brainstem. In a CT scan image, the medulla appears as a tapered structure at the base of the brain, just below the pons. It has a similar density to the adjacent brain tissue. The medulla plays a crucial role in controlling vital functions such as breathing, heart rate, blood pressure, and reflexes.

Cerebellum (Option D): The cerebellum is a region located at the back of the brain, below the occipital lobes of the cerebrum. In a CT scan image, the cerebellum appears as a distinct structure with a granular appearance. It is characterized by its distinctive lobes and folia (ridged surface). The density of the cerebellum is similar to that of other brain tissues. The cerebellum is involved in coordinating voluntary movements, balance, posture, and motor learning.

questions.text: A patient complains of neck stiffness and severe headache. The CT image shown below is suggestive of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Subarachnoid hemorrhage

Explanation:

  • The presence of blood in the cisterns on a CT scan is a hallmark of a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). SAH occurs due to bleeding into the subarachnoid space, often caused by the rupture of an aneurysm or trauma.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH)

Definition

Presence of blood in the subarachnoid space, typically from a ruptured cerebral aneurysm or trauma.

Clinical Features
  • Sudden, severe headache (often described as a "thunderclap headache")
  • Worst headache ever experienced by the patient.

Etiology
  • Traumatic: Head injuries causing bleeding in the subarachnoid space.
  • Non-Traumatic: Most commonly due to rupture of a cerebral aneurysm.

Initial Imaging

Non-Contrast CT (NCCT): First-line imaging for suspected SAH, effective in the acute setting.

Radiological Findings (NCCT)

Appearance of Blood: Hyperdense (white) compared to surrounding cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

Common Sites for Blood Accumulation:

  • Interhemispheric Fissure
  • Sylvian Fissure
  • Suprasellar Cistern
  • Perimesencephalic Cistern

Distinctive Shape: Blood may take on a pentagon or star shape, referred to as the "Star of Death."

Additional Investigations

CT Angiography: Visualizes potential aneurysms or vascular malformations; useful for rupture suspicion.

Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA): Gold standard for diagnosing cerebral aneurysms; provides detailed vascular images and therapeutic options (e.g., endovascular coiling).

Incorrect Options:

Meningitis (Option A): Presents with headache, neck stiffness, and fever but does not show blood on CT. Meningitis may show leptomeningeal enhancement on MRI or CT with contrast.

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage (Option C): Blood would appear within the brain parenchyma, not in the cisterns. Common causes include hypertension or trauma.

Hemorrhagic stroke (Option D): While hemorrhagic strokes can include intraparenchymal or subarachnoid hemorrhages, the specific finding of blood in the cisterns points more specifically to subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with a 7-month history of progressive dysphagia and bad breath. An image is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Zenker diverticulum

Explanation:

 

  • The given image is a barium swallow radiograph showing a posterior outpouching at the pharyngoesophageal junction, characteristic of Zenker's diverticulum.
  • Zenker diverticulum is a pharyngoesophageal diverticulum that develops due to weakness in the Killian's triangle (between the inferior pharyngeal constrictor and cricopharyngeus muscle).

Zenker Diverticulum:

  • False pulsion diverticulum as it protrudes posteriorly above the cricopharyngeal sphincter through the dehiscence of Kilian between the oblique and horizontal fibres of the inferior pharnygeal constrictor.
  • It is due to loss of coordination between pharyngeal contraction and opening of the upper esophagal sphincter.

 

Clinical features

  • When the diverticulum is small, symptoms largely reflect desynchronization of swallowing with pharyngeal dysphagia.
  • As the pouch enlarges:
    • The fundus descends into the mediastinum.
    • Regurgitation of trapped food can occur and lead to aspiration.
    • Main symptom is halitosis and regurgitation.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Barium Swallow Study (Esophagram): To visualize the esophagus and identify the presence of a diverticulum.

 

  • Esophagal Manometry
  • MRI
  • Endoscopy

 

Surgical treatment :

  • Diverticulectomy and cricopharyngeus myotomy
  • Diverticular suspension: The diverticulum is dissected and absence of a suture line lessens the chance of a postoperative leak.
  • Cricopharyngeus myotomy
  • Newer techniques: Transoral introduction of a linear stapler.

Achalasia (Option A):

  • Typically presents with dysphagia to both solids and liquids from the onset due to impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter.
  • Barium Swallow Finding: Classic "bird’s beak" appearance, showing a dilated esophagus with tapering at the lower esophageal sphincter.

 

Carcinoma esophagus (Option B):

  • Presents with progressive dysphagia (first to solids, then liquids) along with weight loss and possible odynophagia.
  • The provided image does not show an irregular mass or luminal narrowing typical of malignancy.

 

Diffuse esophageal spasm (Option D):

  • Characterized by intermittent, non-progressive dysphagia and chest pain, often relieved by nitrates or calcium channel blockers.
  • The imaging here does not show the classic "corkscrew esophagus" seen in esophageal spasm.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male arrived at the emergency room after being involved in a car accident. During the examination, his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was E2M2V3, indicating a level of consciousness. No fractures, hydrocephalus, or increased pressure within the skull were detected. A non-contrast CT scan was conducted and showed no abnormalities. The probable diagnosis is-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI)

Explanation:

  • Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of E2M2V3 (Total: 7) suggests a severe traumatic brain injury (TBI).

  • History of a car accident suggests high-velocity trauma, which is a common cause of DAI.

  • Normal CT scan does not rule out DAI, as it often presents with microscopic damage to axons, which may not be visible on a non-contrast CT but can be detected using MRI (susceptibility-weighted imaging or DWI).

  • Absence of hydrocephalus, fractures, or increased intracranial pressure further supports DAI, as other traumatic brain injuries (like hemorrhages or herniation) would likely show visible abnormalities on CT.

Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI)

 

Feature

Description

Etiology

High-speed trauma, rotational forces, falls

Mechanism

Shearing of axons due to rapid acceleration/deceleration

Clinical Features

Unconsciousness, low GCS, no focal deficits

Imaging Findings

Normal CT initially; MRI shows microhemorrhages (FLAIR, GRE sequences)

Management

Supportive care, ICU monitoring, neuroprotection

 

 

Post-concussion syndrome (Option B): Incorrect because post-concussion syndrome usually follows mild TBI, with symptoms like headache, dizziness, and mood changes, but does not cause low GCS.

Extradural hemorrhage (Option C): Incorrect because extradural (epidural) hemorrhage appears as a biconvex hyperdense lesion on CT, often with a lucid interval, which is absent here.

Herniation of brain (Option D): Incorrect because brain herniation would show CT signs like midline shift, compressed ventricles, and brainstem displacement, none of which are seen in this case.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented with chronic back pain and neck stiffness. An X-ray cervical spine is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis (DISH)

Explanation:

  • Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis (DISH) is a condition characterized by calcification and ossification of ligaments, particularly the anterior longitudinal ligament of the spine.
  • On X-ray, it presents as flowing ossifications along the anterolateral aspect of at least four contiguous vertebrae without significant disc space narrowing or sacroiliac joint involvement.

Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis (DISH)

Feature

Description

Etiology

Unknown; associated with metabolic conditions (e.g., diabetes)

Radiological Features

Continuous flowing ossifications over vertebral bodies, preservation of disc spaces

Common Location

Cervical and thoracic spine

Symptoms

Stiffness, chronic pain, dysphagia if cervical involvement

Differential Diagnosis

Ankylosing spondylitis, degenerative disc disease

Management

Symptomatic treatment with NSAIDs, physical therapy

 

57-year-old male patient diagnosed with both Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis and Spondyloarthritis. Technique: Lateral and Antero-Posterior (AP) X-rays of the thoracic Spine Findings: Flowing ossifications involving the anterior longitudinal ligament along multiple contiguous thoracic levels with preservation of the intervertebral disc height at the involved

A case of diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis involving only cervical spine (C3-6). Flowing bridging ossification and partial ossification (arrows) of three contiguous disc levels (C3-6) are noted in consecutive sagittal images (A, B) of whole spine computed tomography.

 

Ankylosing spondylitis (Option A): Incorrect because it typically involves sacroiliac joint fusion and syndesmophytes rather than flowing ossifications.

Klippel-Feil syndrome (Option C): Incorrect because it is a congenital disorder with cervical vertebral fusion, not ossification of ligaments.

Sprengel deformity (Option D): Incorrect because it presents with congenital elevation of the scapula, not spinal ligament ossification.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male was brought to the emergency room after being involved in a car accident. During the examination, his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was E2M2V3. There were no fractures, hydrocephalus, or increased pressure within the skull. A non-contrast CT scan was conducted and revealed no abnormalities. The suspected diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Diffuse axonal injury

Explanation:

  • The patient’s Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of E2M2V3 indicates a severe alteration in consciousness, likely due to diffuse brain injury. Non-contrast CT may show no abnormalities, especially in the early stages of diffuse axonal injury, which primarily affects the white matter of the brain. This injury is commonly seen in traumatic brain injury (TBI), especially in high-velocity accidents like car crashes. Clinical signs such as altered consciousness, coma, and normal CT findings are suggestive of diffuse axonal injury.

Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI)

  • A form of primary brain injury caused by widespread damage to axons due to rotational acceleration and deceleration forces, often associated with high-energy trauma.

Causes:

  • Rotational forces: High-energy accidents involving rapid acceleration and deceleration (e.g., motor vehicle collisions).
  • Trauma: Blunt force impacts that cause the brain to rotate within the skull.

Clinical Features:

  • Impaired arousal: Often presents as coma or reduced consciousness due to damage in critical brain areas (e.g., pontine reticular activating system, bilateral thalami).
  • Neurological deficits: Poor neurological examination, despite the absence of obvious radiographic global brain injury.
  • Irreversible consequences: DAI is often associated with severe and lasting neurological impairment.

Investigations:

  • CT scan: May show hemorrhagic foci in the corpus callosum and dorsolateral rostral brainstem in severe cases.
  • MRI:
    • More sensitive than CT.
    • It shows small haemorrhages and diffuse axonal injury, particularly in patients who fail to improve neurologically.
  • Postmortem examination: Confirms the diagnosis with axonal disruption and formation of axon balls.

Prognosis: Very poor due to high risk of severe disability or death due to extensive brain damage.

 

Post-concussion syndrome (option B): This is incorrect because post-concussion syndrome typically develops days to weeks after a mild traumatic brain injury and usually presents with headaches, dizziness, and cognitive issues. The acute severe presentation in this case, especially the GCS of 7 (severe impairment), is more consistent with a diffuse axonal injury.

Extradural haemorrhage (option C): This is incorrect because an extradural haemorrhage usually appears on CT as a lens-shaped, hyperdense collection of blood and typically presents with a history of skull fracture. In this case, the CT scan was normal.

Herniation of brain (option D): This is incorrect because herniation typically results in changes on CT, such as midline shift or loss of brain structures, which were not observed in the scan. Additionally, herniation would likely present with clinical signs such as pupillary dilation or abnormal posturing, none of which are described here.

questions.text: Which of the following MRI imaging techniques is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) T2 MRI

Explanation:

  • A T2-weighted MRI sequence highlights fluid as hyperintense (bright) and soft tissues differently compared to T1-weighted MRI. It is particularly useful in detecting edema, inflammation, and CSF-filled structures.

Key Features of T2-Weighted MRI:

  • CSF and fluids appear bright (white)
  • Edema and inflammation are hyperintense
  • Gray matter appears slightly brighter than white matter
  • Fat appears relatively darker compared to T1

MRI Sequences & Their Characteristics

MRI Sequence

CSF Appearance

Fat Appearance

Use Cases

T1-weighted

Dark

Bright

Anatomy, fat-containing lesions

T2-weighted

Bright

Darker

Edema, inflammation, tumors

FLAIR

Dark

Dark

White matter lesions, periventricular pathology

STIR

Dark

Dark

Suppresses fat signal, good for musculoskeletal imaging

T1 MRI (Option A): Incorrect because CSF appears dark in T1, while it is bright in the given T2 image.

STIR (Option C): Incorrect because STIR suppresses fat signal but does not necessarily highlight fluids as in T2-weighted imaging.

FLAIR (Option D): Incorrect because FLAIR suppresses CSF signal, making it dark, while in T2 it remains bright.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Internal Capsule

Explanation:

Internal Capsule:

  • The internal capsule is a white matter structure in the brain that separates the caudate nucleus (medially) from the putamen and globus pallidus (laterally).
  • It contains major ascending and descending tracts, including corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts, which are responsible for motor and sensory functions.
  • In the given image, the structure appears as a dense white matter band in the coronal plane, consistent with the location of the internal capsule.

 

External capsule (option A): Incorrect because the external capsule is a thin white matter layer located lateral to the putamen, separating it from the claustrum. It is not the structure shown in this image.

Caudate nucleus (option C): Incorrect because the caudate nucleus is located medial to the internal capsule, near the lateral ventricles. It appears as a grey matter structure and is not consistent with the marked region.

Putamen (option D): Incorrect because the putamen is located lateral to the internal capsule and is part of the basal ganglia. It appears as a grey matter structure and does not match the highlighted structure.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the OPD with a parietal swelling present since birth. The X-ray image is given below. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Cephalohematoma

Explanation:

Cephalohematoma (subperiosteal hematoma) presents as a well-circumscribed, firm mass over the parietal bones that does not cross suture lines. It typically develops in the first few hours after birth, with increasing size for 12-24 hours, and then stabilizes. This fits the description provided in the scenario.

Characteristic

Caput Succedaneum

(Option C ruled out)

Cephalohematoma

(Option B)

Incidence

Common

Less common

Location

Subcutaneous plane

Over parietal bones, between the skull and periosteum.

Time of Presentation

Maximum size and firmness at birth.

Develops during the 1st few hours of life. Increasing size for 12-24 hours and then stable.

Time Course

Softens progressively from birth.

Takes 3-6 weeks to resolve, but may resolve within 2-3 days.

Characteristic Findings
  • Diffuse Circular boggy area of oedema with indistinct borders.
  • Often with overlying ecchymosis
  • Crosses suture line
  • Well-circumscribed fluid-filled mass.
  • Does not cross the suture line

Association

None

Linear skull fracture (5-25%); hyperbilirubinemia

 

Subgaleal Hemorrhage (Option A) is a more diffuse, larger haemorrhage that crosses suture lines and is associated with more severe symptoms. It is less likely to present as a firm, well-defined mass and is typically associated with significant blood loss, which is not described in the scenario.

Encephalocele (Option D): Encephalocele is a neural tube defect characterized by sac-like protrusions of the brain and the membranes that cover it through openings in the skull. It appears as an external bulge in the skull and requires surgical intervention.

questions.text: A patient presented with a head injury after a hammer fell on the skull. CT is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option C - Depressed skull fracture:

  • A depressed skull fracture occurs when a portion of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain.
  • This type of fracture often occurs from blunt trauma to the head, such as being hit by a heavy object.

Incorrect options: Option A, B and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Identify the radiological image of the condition given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Paget's disease

Explanation:

  • The above-given skull X-ray shows a cotton wool appearance, which is suggestive of Paget's disease.

 

Paget's Disease of Bone:

Paget’s disease (osteitis deformans):

  • A non-neoplastic condition that is characterised by abnormal bone remodelling.
  • Clinical features:
    • Seen in elderly patients
    • Presents with bone pain, sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) (cranial nerve compression)
    • Cardiac failure (hyperdynamic circulation)
    • Raised alkaline phosphatase (ALP), but calcium and phosphorous levels are normal
  • Radiological features:

Osteoporosis circumscripta: A circumscribed patch of osteoporosis in the skull.

The cotton wool appearance of the skull (due to sclerosis)

Tam O'Shanter sign: The skull's expansion and flattened base create the appearance of the skull tilting over the facial structures (due to the thickening of the frontal bone).

 

Blade of grass appearance or candle flame sign: Flame-shaped lesion extending along the shaft of the bone.

Picture frame vertebra:

The vertebrae appear enlarged and have a thickened cortical bone due to excessive bone remodeling and disorganized osteoblastic activity.

 

Ivory vertebra:

The homogeneous, radiopaque appearance results from increased bone density caused by abnormal osteoblastic activity, leading to excessive bone formation.

 

Lincoln sign or Black Beard sign: Increased radiotracer uptake in the mandible gives it a distinctive black beard appearance that signifies abnormal bone metabolism in Paget’s disease.

Banana fractures: Occur in a region of abnormal bone.

 

Multiple Myeloma (Option B): Punched-out lytic lesions of the skull or Raindrop lesions are seen in Multiple myeloma.

Hyperparathyroidism (Option C): Salt and pepper appearance is seen in hyperparathyroidism.

Sickle cell anemia (Option D): Sickle cell anemia is characterized by hair-on-end appearance of skull on X-ray.

questions.text: Which visual field defect is likely to be caused by the lesion shown in the given radiograph?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bitemporal hemianopia:

  • The radiograph in question shows a craniopharyngioma, which is a suprasellar mass located above the optic chiasma. It compresses the optic chiasma and causes bitemporal hemianopia.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are not typically caused by craniopharyngioma.

questions.text: Using the radiograph provided, which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Chiari type 1 malformation:

  • Chiari type 1 malformation is characterized by a small posterior fossa, which leads to herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Dandy-Walker malformation: Dandy-Walker malformation is characterized by a large posterior fossa and the presence of a posterior fossa cyst.

Option C - Vein of Galen malformation: The vein of Galen malformation is identified by an enlarged vein of Galen on imaging.

Option D - Corpus callosum agenesis: Agenesis of the corpus callosum refers to the absence or underdevelopment of the corpus callosum, but it is seen in the given image.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient complains of a persistent headache. A CT scan of the head was performed, as shown below. What is the most accurate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH):

The given image of the NCCT head shows a star of death appearance, which is a characteristic feature of subarachnoid hemorrhage. The structures which appear white are:

  • Interhemispheric fissure
  • Sylvian fissure
  • Suprasellar cistern
  • Peri mesencephalic cistern

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Epidural hemorrhage: EDH typically appears as a biconvex or lentiform shape on a CT scan.

 

Option C - Subdural hemorrhage: SDH usually presents as a crescent-shaped or sickle-shaped hemorrhage.

Option D - Intraparenchymal hemorrhage: Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage will show a hyperdense pathology.

questions.text: From the provided MRI, please identify the medical condition observed in the lower back of the newborn, which presents as an abnormal lump.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • The given MRI image is suggestive of a meningocele which represents CSF filled cavity in the Lumbosacral region surrounded by meninges, which is making a protrusion over the lumbosacral region. It is a T2 WI image that shows CSF filled white cystic cavity known as a meningocele. 
  • Meningocele is a birth defect where the affected individual has a sac filled with spinal fluid-filled protruding from the spinal cord.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Myelomeningocele: The MRI image of myelomeningocele shows a protruding neural placode extending beyond the skin surface as an enlargement of the underlying subarachnoid space. Since the given image does not show this, it is suggestive that the option is incorrect.

Option C - Spina Bifida Occulta: A plain radiograph in this condition would show a midline or para-midline bony defect at the posterior arch. Therefore, it is an incorrect option.

Option D - Bone cyst: It is a cystic lesion inside the bone seen on X-ray as a lesion filled with fluid. Since the given findings do not match the description, it is considered an incorrect choice.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			A. Epidural hematoma
			
			
			i. 
			
		
		
			
			B. Subdural hematoma
			
			
			ii. 
			
		
		
			
			C. Subarchniod hemorrhage
			
			
			iii. 
			
		
		
			
			D. Intracerebral hemorrhage
			
			
			iv.
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option b. A-ii, B-iv, C-i, D-iii:

Epidural hematoma (A) typically presents as a lens-shaped collection of blood between the skull and the dura mater, which is assigned to ii.

Subdural hematoma (B), a collection of blood between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater, is assigned to iv.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (C), bleeding into the subarachnoid space, is assigned to i.

Intracerebral hemorrhage (D), bleeding within the brain tissue itself, is assigned to iii.

Incorrect options

Options A, C, and D are incorrectly matched.

questions.text: Please determine the anatomical structure indicated in the provided MRI scan.
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: Cerebellum is a distinct structure located at the back of the brain, beneath the occipital lobes of the cerebrum. It plays a crucial role in motor coordination, balance, and posture. The MRI scan clearly shows the cerebellum as the marked structure, making it the correct option.

 

Incorrect options

Option A: Midbrain is a part of the brainstem located above the pons and below the cerebral hemispheres. It plays a role in various functions such as motor control, visual and auditory processing. The MRI scan shown does not depict the midbrain; instead, it focuses on the posterior aspect of the brain.

Option C: Brainstem refers to the lower part of the brain that connects the cerebrum with the spinal cord. It consists of the midbrain, pons, and medulla oblongata. While the MRI scan includes a portion of the brainstem, the structure marked in the image is specifically the cerebellum, not the entire brainstem.

Option D: Cerebrum is the largest part of the brain and is responsible for various higher cognitive functions such as memory, language, perception, and conscious thought. The MRI scan does not primarily focus on the cerebrum, but rather on the posterior aspect of the brain, which includes the cerebellum.

questions.text: A child presents with left to right shunt and high output cardiac failure. The following is his MRA. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Vein of Galen malformation

  • The given MRA image showing the abnormality in the Vein of Galen supports this diagnosis. Vein of Galen malformation is a rare but significant condition that requires specialized management and treatment.
  • Vein of Galen malformation. It is a rare congenital vascular abnormality involving the malformation of the deep cerebral veins, resulting in an abnormal connection between the arterial and venous systems within the brain.
  • This abnormality leads to a left to right shunt, where blood flows directly from high-pressure arterial circulation to low-pressure venous circulation, causing a high-output cardiac failure.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Dandy Walker syndrome- Dandy Walker syndrome is a congenital brain malformation characterized by the absence or underdevelopment of the cerebellar vermis, cystic enlargement of the fourth ventricle, and an enlarged posterior fossa. It is not related to the MRA image provided, which shows a vascular abnormality rather than a brain malformation.

Option C: Pneumocephalus- Pneumocephalus refers to the presence of air or gas within the cranial cavity. It typically occurs as a result of trauma, surgery, or infection. The MRA image does not show any evidence of pneumocephalus, and it is not related to the symptoms of left to right shunt and high-output cardiac failure mentioned in the question.

Option D. Venous sinus thrombosis: Venous sinus thrombosis is a condition characterized by the formation of blood clots within the dural venous sinuses, which are large veins that drain blood from the brain. It can cause a variety of symptoms, including headache, seizures, and neurological deficits. However, the MRA image provided does not show any evidence of venous sinus thrombosis, and it is not associated with the typical presentation of left to right shunt and high-output cardiac failure.

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the shown CT:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • Massive epidural hemorrhage, also known as epidural hematoma, is a serious medical condition characterized by bleeding between the outer lining of the brain (dura mater) and the skull. It is typically caused by a traumatic injury to the head, such as a skull fracture or severe impact
  • On a CT scan, a massive epidural hemorrhage appears as a convex, lens-shaped collection of blood that is located between the skull and the dura mater. The blood appears hyperdense (bright) compared to the surrounding brain tissue. The hemorrhage can exert pressure on the brain, leading to potentially life-threatening complications if not promptly addressed.

Incorrect Option:

Option A: Intraventricular bleed: Intraventricular bleeding refers to bleeding that occurs within the brain's ventricles. It is characterized by blood accumulation within the ventricular system. On a CT scan, intraventricular bleeding appears as hyperdense areas within the ventricles. It is often associated with other types of bleeding, such as subarachnoid hemorrhage or intracerebral hemorrhage. However, in the given scenario, the CT scan does not show blood accumulation within the ventricles, making intraventricular bleed an incorrect choice.

Option C: Subdural hemorrhage: Subdural hemorrhage refers to bleeding that occurs between the dura mater (outermost layer of the brain) and the arachnoid mater (the middle layer). It is typically caused by trauma and can lead to the collection of blood in the subdural space. On a CT scan, subdural hemorrhage appears as a crescent-shaped collection of blood between the brain and the dura mater. In the given scenario, there is no evidence of blood accumulation in the subdural space, making subdural hemorrhage an incorrect choice.

Option D: Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Subarachnoid hemorrhage refers to bleeding that occurs in the subarachnoid space, which is the space between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater (innermost layer of the brain). It is commonly caused by the rupture of an intracranial aneurysm or head trauma. On a CT scan, subarachnoid hemorrhage appears as diffuse or localized areas of high-density blood within the subarachnoid space. In the given scenario, there is no evidence of blood within the subarachnoid space, making subarachnoid hemorrhage an incorrect choice
